text: Thus will I bless thee while I live: I will lift up my hands in thy name.
text_kjv: Thus will I bless thee while I live: I will lift up my hands in thy name.
text_niv: I will praise you as long as I live,and in your name I will lift up my hands.
text_esv: So I will bless you as long as I live; in your name I will lift up my hands.
text_nlt: I will praise you as long as I live,lifting up my hands to you in prayer.
text_msg: I bless you every time I take a breath;My arms wave like banners of praise to you.
text_nasb: So I will bless You as long as I live; I will lift up my hands in Your name.
context: Psalm 63 is attributed to David, composed while he was in the wilderness of Judah. This likely refers to the period when David was fleeing from his son Absalom (2 Samuel 15-18), or possibly during his earlier flight from King Saul. The wilderness of Judah is a desolate and arid region, offering little comfort or sustenance. It served as a stark backdrop against which David's deep longing for God is expressed. Understanding the setting is crucial; David was not in a palace, surrounded by luxury and security, but rather in a physically and emotionally vulnerable state. The phrase 'lift up my hands' has deep roots in ancient Near Eastern worship practices. Lifting the hands towards the sky was a common posture of supplication, adoration, and dependence on a higher power. It signified both an acknowledgment of God's sovereignty and an appeal for His mercy. It wasn't merely a physical gesture; it symbolized an internal attitude of humility and reliance. The phrase 'in thy name' is equally important. In Hebrew thought, a name represents the essence and character of a person. To invoke God's name was to call upon His very being, His power, and His promises. David wasn't simply offering empty praise; he was expressing his blessing and worship in the context of God's revealed character and covenant faithfulness. His desire for God was not an abstract philosophical longing, but a deep, personal yearning for the God he knew intimately.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 63:4 encapsulates several vital truths about the relationship between God and humanity. 'Thus will I bless thee while I live' demonstrates the ongoing, continuous nature of worship. It’s not a one-time event or a sporadic occurrence, but a lifelong commitment. David’s intention is to bless God continually, acknowledging His worthiness and expressing gratitude for His presence. This highlights the importance of consistent devotion, regardless of circumstances. 'I will lift up my hands in thy name' further underscores the personal and relational aspect of worship. The act of lifting up hands signifies surrender and dependence. It symbolizes a willingness to receive from God and to submit to His will. It also demonstrates a posture of expectancy, anticipating God's blessing and intervention. Lifting hands 'in thy name' highlights the importance of worship being directed to the true God, the God revealed in Scripture. It’s not just any generic deity, but the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, the God who has made covenants and demonstrated His faithfulness throughout history. The verse emphasizes the active role of the worshipper. David isn’t passively receiving; he's actively choosing to bless God. This active engagement highlights the importance of intentionality in worship. It's not enough to simply go through the motions; we must actively engage our hearts and minds in praising God. This verse, taken within the entire Psalm, also illustrates the priority of God's presence. Even in the desolation of the wilderness, David's greatest desire is for God Himself, surpassing any earthly comfort or security.
application: In today's world, Psalm 63:4 provides a powerful model for our own worship and devotion. 'Thus will I bless thee while I live' challenges us to cultivate a lifestyle of consistent worship. This means integrating praise and gratitude into our daily routines, not just confining it to Sunday mornings. We can bless God through our words, actions, and attitudes, consciously seeking to honor Him in all that we do. This looks like choosing gratitude over grumbling, extending kindness to others, and living with integrity in our daily dealings. The phrase 'I will lift up my hands' encourages us to embrace vulnerability and humility in our worship. While physical gestures may vary across cultures and personal preferences, the underlying principle remains the same: we should approach God with a posture of openness and surrender. This means acknowledging our dependence on Him and being willing to submit to His will. Practically, this could involve setting aside time for quiet reflection and prayer, actively participating in corporate worship, or engaging in acts of service that demonstrate our love for God and others. Lifting hands 'in thy name' reminds us that our worship should be grounded in the truth of God's Word. It's not about empty rituals or emotional experiences, but about encountering the living God in all His glory and power. This requires us to continually grow in our knowledge of God through studying Scripture, engaging in theological reflection, and seeking guidance from the Holy Spirit. Furthermore, in a culture often obsessed with self-promotion and achievement, this verse calls us to re-center our lives on God. It reminds us that true fulfillment comes not from our own accomplishments but from a deep and abiding relationship with Him. We can consciously shift our focus from seeking external validation to seeking God's approval, finding our identity and worth in Him.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you with a heart filled with gratitude and longing. Like David in the wilderness, I recognize my dependence on you. Teach me to bless you while I live, not just in moments of joy but also in times of difficulty. Help me to lift up my hands to you in humble surrender, acknowledging your sovereignty and seeking your guidance. May my worship be authentic and heartfelt, rooted in the truth of your Word and fueled by the power of your Spirit. Forgive me for the times when I have neglected to praise you or have allowed distractions to steal my attention. Fill me with a renewed passion for you and a desire to live a life that brings glory to your name. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Blessing God doesn't imply making Him better. Rather, it expresses our recognition of His inherent goodness, power, and worthiness. It is an act of ascribing praise and honor to Him, acknowledging His perfect character and works. We bless Him by declaring His greatness.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean to 'bless God' if He is already perfect?

faqs.answer: While lifting hands is a biblical expression of worship, it is not the sole requirement for genuine worship. The heart's attitude of humility, reverence, and obedience is paramount. The physical act should reflect an inner disposition of adoration and surrender to God's will.
faqs.question: Q2: Is the act of lifting hands necessary for genuine worship?

faqs.answer: Even in difficult times, you can bless God by choosing to focus on His character and promises. Praying with thanksgiving, remembering past blessings, and trusting in His sovereignty can all be acts of blessing Him amidst suffering. Focus on what you DO have instead of what you LACK.
faqs.question: Q3: How can I practically 'bless God' during a difficult season in my life?

faqs.answer: Blessing God 'in His name' means acknowledging and honoring all that He is. We are recognizing His character, attributes, and the power associated with His revealed identity. We acknowledge His authority and promises contained within His name.
faqs.question: Q4: What is the significance of blessing God 'in His name'?

faqs.answer: Lifting up hands can symbolize intercessory prayer. As we lift our hands, we can lift up the needs and burdens of others to God, interceding on their behalf. It's an act of dependence on God's power to intervene and bring healing and restoration.
